metadata.title: 8 Cognitive Biases Facing Data Scientists | by GreekDataGuy | Towards Data Science
metadata.description: But cognitive biases, subconscious irrational thinking patterns, can lead us to make poor decisions ourselves. I’ve going to share 8 cognitive biases and examples I’ve faced in my career as a…

all_paragraphs: As data scientists, we help companies make optimal decisions.
But cognitive biases, subconscious irrational thinking patterns, can lead us to make poor decisions ourselves.
I’ve going to share 8 cognitive biases and examples I’ve faced in my career as a software engineering and data scientist.
Called the “Sunk Cost Fallacy” in economics.

Escalation of commitment is a human behavior pattern in which an individual or group facing increasingly negative outcomes from a decision, action, or investment nevertheless continues the behavior instead of altering course.-Wikipedia
It’s the tendency to continue investing resources into an existing project despite evidence that remaining costs outweigh benefits, justified by having already invested significant resources.
In for a penny, in for a pound.
After working on a new NLP pipeline for a month, I learned it would only perform marginally better than an existing model.

The new model would take another week to complete and there were other available projects requiring my skills. Despite this, I had a strong desire to finish the current project because I’d already invested so much time. This is “escalation of commitment”.
Logically, if the marginal benefit of working on something else is higher, you should do that instead.
That said, this cognitive bias may be so well ingrained in an organization that you don’t have a choice but to finish a current project, if only for optics (aka. so you don’t look bad).
Underestimating how long a project will take to complete.
The planning fallacy is a phenomenon in which predictions about how much time will be needed to complete a future task display an optimism bias and underestimate the time needed.-Wikipedia
Software engineers and data scientists are famous for massively underestimating the time it takes to build things.

I’ve had technical staff who underestimated the time to complete every single feature during their time at my company. This is despite 1-on-1s where I explicitly told them to double their estimates (to no avail) so they wouldn’t look bad to management.
My personal rule of thumb is to 2x my project timelines. Anecdotally this turns out to be closer to the actual required time.
Confirmation bias is the tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms or strengthens one’s prior personal beliefs or values.-Wikipedia
Confirmation bias is unintentionally cherry picking information that agrees with a given hypothesis.

I’ve several colleagues who’ve been told by a manager to find evidence better supporting a specific argument (rather than taking a proper sample). While this direction can come from the top, it can also manifest subconsciously as you look for evidence to support/disqualify a new feature you want to build.
In my experience, the best way to ward off confirmation bias is deciding how an experiment/feature will be evaluated before beginning the work.
The curse of knowledge is a cognitive bias that occurs when an individual, communicating with other individuals, unknowingly assumes that the others have the background to understand.-Wikipedia
People with a strong competency in a given area can have trouble explaining related concepts to others who lack the technical background.
I once had a really inquisitive non-technical executive who’d ask me technical questions out of the blue. How does a word embedding work? What’s an XYZ index in Postgres?
Being the type who needs to think before speaking, I’d often fumble trying to figure out how to explain it to someone without a background. That’s the curse of knowledge.
I originally started writing on medium to help me clarify my thoughts and improve my ability in explaining.
The bias blind spot is the cognitive bias of recognizing the impact of biases on the judgment of others, while failing to see the impact of biases on one’s own judgment.
We recognize biases in other people but not ourselves.
I’ve developed a strong aversion to unsupervised learning after a number of failed experiments in which it didn’t solve a given problem.
This becomes problematic when the bias causes me to shoot down unsupervised learning solutions during brainstorming sessions without truely considering their merits.
Past experience shouldn’t jade one from proper analysis or valuable opportunities could be missed. Seeing biases in yourself requires a great deal of introspection (or really honest colleagues).

Groupthink is a psychological phenomenon that occurs within a group of people in which the desire for harmony or conformity in the group results in an irrational or dysfunctional decision-making outcome.-Wikipedia
A subconscious desire for agreement overrides rational decision making.
Having graduated multiple startup accelerators including Techstars, I’ve come to the conclusion that this is the norm inside startups.
In a previous company, co-founders (including myself) rode a wave of self-reinforced optimism to failure. As a group, we underestimated development complexity and overestimated customer adoption.
A number of interesting studies and articles have been written on group think including NASA’s Challenger Disaster.

The concept known as the law of the instrument, otherwise known as the law of the hammer,[1] Maslow’s hammer (or gavel), or the golden hammer,[a] is a cognitive bias that involves an over-reliance on a familiar tool.-Wikipedia
A bias towards using familiar tools, even when they can be suboptimal for a task.
If all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail. — Abraham Maslow
When I first got into machine learning the only library I was comfortable with was sklearn. So every time a new task came up, I figured out how to use sklearn to solve it.

That worked well until I got deep into NLP for which there were a number of more appropriate packages. Time was wasted while I tried to hack solutions with what I knew rather than exploring better options.
Now I try to start with a clean slate on every problem, evaluate existing tools, as well as research new tools.
The bandwagon effect is a phenomenon whereby the rate of uptake of beliefs, ideas, fads and trends increases the more that they have already been adopted by others.- Wikipedia
Doing something a certain way because you repeatedly hear of others doing it, rather than performing an objective evaluation yourself.
Let’s just throw it at a neural network.

I’ve heard suggestions of using a neural network in too many cases when a less complex model would suffice. I blame this on the bandwagon affect and people constantly hearing about neural networks in the news.
Anecdotally, I’d guess most “AI-powered” products are NOT powered by deep learning. But you’d get the opposite impression reading the MIT Technology Review or Tech Crunch.

We live in an extremely complex world where analyzing every piece of information isn’t possible. I’d hypothesize we developed some of these biases to reduce the mental overhead associated with routine activities.

Some heuristics are helpful. Some are not. But by definition, if we can reduce the effect of these well-studied negative biases on ourselves, we can become more effective decision makers in our organizations.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Just a developer. Contact: greek.data.guy “at” gmail.com
